technique_notes: Use a spiral pouring motion and aim for a total brew time of 2:30 to bring out the floral notes.
After pouring, stir gently once to ensure all grounds are saturated before placing the lid on.
The thick filter is key; rinse it well with hot water to avoid a papery taste in the final cup.
Use the inverted method and a 90-second steep time to maximize the rich, earthy body.
Press the plunger slowly and steadily to minimize sediment in your cup.
A 45-second bloom with 60g of water will enhance the chocolatey and spicy notes.
Press gently over 30 seconds for a cleaner, brighter cup that highlights the citrus finish.
Pour slowly and in stages to delicately extract the complex floral and fruit notes of the Geisha.
A slightly coarser grind and lower temperature will emphasize the sweet, jammy fruit notes of this natural processed bean.
A 4-minute steep time is perfect for balancing the sweet caramel and nutty flavors.
Focus on an even pour to bring out the bright, juicy red apple and orange zest notes.
A quick 60-second steep before plunging creates a wonderfully smooth and balanced cup.
This bean shines with a clean brew; ensure a steady pour rate for a creamy, sweet result.
Higher temperature water will unlock the vibrant blackberry and lemon notes in this peaberry.
Use a slightly lower temperature to highlight the dark chocolate and plum notes without over-extraction.
Create a powerful, espresso-like concentrate; dilute with hot water to your preferred strength.
Use two paper filters for a cleaner, richer body that mimics a classic Italian espresso.
The honey processing benefits from a gentle pulse pour to develop its sweet tropical fruit notes.
A meticulous, slow pour is required to extract the delicate green tea and red currant flavors.
Embrace the sediment; the wild, winey notes of Yemen Mocha are best expressed with immersion.
To preserve its famous smoothness, avoid overly hot water and aim for a 3-minute brew time.
This delicate coffee shines in a Chemex, which produces a clean cup to highlight its subtle sweetness.
Let it steep for a full 2 minutes before pressing to develop the syrupy body and savory notes.
Keep your kettle high during the pour to increase agitation and enhance the bright, citrusy acidity.
This complex coffee needs high extraction; use multiple pours and agitate the slurry with a gentle swirl.
A lower temperature and longer steep time (4:30) will bring out the deep chocolate and fig notes.
This unique coffee has very low acidity; don't be afraid of a longer steep to develop its earthy character.
For a classic, balanced cup, use the standard (non-inverted) method and plunge right after pouring.
Break the crust at 1 minute and scoop the foam off the top for a cleaner Robusta experience.
Rinse the filter thoroughly to ensure the bold, winey notes of the Harrar are not muted by paper taste.
A longer steep of 4:30 minutes will fully develop the earthy and herbal notes characteristic of Gayo.
Use the inverted method and a slow 45-second plunge to capture the silky body and spicy finish.
Maintain a consistent, slow pour in a spiral motion to accentuate the bright citrus and sweet orange notes.
The thick Chemex filter creates an exceptionally clean cup, perfect for highlighting the unique floral and licorice notes.
A standard, upright brew with a 90-second steep time yields a balanced and smooth cup every time.
Break the crust at 1 minute to ensure all grounds are saturated, deepening the classic cedar and spice flavors.
A 30-second bloom followed by three even pours will create a well-balanced cup with classic nutty and chocolate notes.
Use higher temperature water and agitate with a gentle swirl after the second pour to bring out the bright passionfruit notes.
A lower temperature and slow pour rate will prevent bitterness and highlight the unique winey acidity and berry notes.
Create a strong, concentrated shot and then dilute with hot water (an 'Americano') to enjoy its bold, nutty flavor.
Use a slightly lower water temperature and a 4-minute steep to bring out the rich chocolate and cedar notes without introducing too much bitterness.
spiral motion
